awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: Documenting Marine Biodiversity through Digitization of Invertebrate Collections (DigIn)
awd_abstract_narration:
For two centuries, America has amassed an unparalleled collection of specimens from exploring the world's oceans. They were pulled up with nets, scooped up from seabeds with grabs, and hand-collected by divers, all contributing to a library of biodiversity that captures the state of life in the ocean - year after year, decade after decade. The broadest evolutionary scope of those collections is in the marine invertebrates, animals without backbones - sea stars, corals, worms, jellyfish, crabs, and thousands of other animals. That library of preserved marine invertebrates is our essential guide to the diversity of ocean life across the globe. And because they encapsulate data from the moment they were picked up, these institutional collections also act as a time machine, letting us use the past to understand how our present will become the future. But there is a problem - vast numbers of these specimens are essentially invisible outside of a tiny community of museum specialists. The only record of these specimens' existence is on labels enclosed in the jars with the preserved animals or in paper logbooks on a shelf. These specimens will remain nearly undiscoverable on museum shelves until their core descriptive information is made digitally available. Therefore, this project will create public digital records for over 7.5 million specimens from our nation's legacy of marine exploration, thereby making the immense investment in the specimens' acquisition available to 21st Century biodiversity and ecosystems research. Because these specimens provide a visible and tangible window into our oceans' enchanting biodiversity, this project will involve STEM educators and student educators in the digitization effort, so that they will be able to reflect their science experiences directly back to the classroom. The public will be involved virtually, by contributing transcription of specimen label data. 

Digitization of alcohol-preserved marine specimens has never been carried out on this scale. A major challenge lies in the location of the data: written, typed, or printed on labels in the jars with the specimens. In many cases, that will require opening the jar, extracting the label, and either transcribing it directly or photographing it for later transcription - for hundreds of thousands of jars. The immediate participants in this program will digitize most or all of the marine invertebrate collections at nineteen institutions across the country, more than doubling the number of digital records for marine invertebrates in the U.S. All data will be publicly available through existing data portals, including iDigBio.org, using standardized data formats, thereby dramatically enhancing the accessibility of biodiversity data for comprehensive, systems-based analysis of ocean ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this collaborative grant is to digitize and share important marine invertebrate collections. These collections hold valuable records of ocean life, which help scientists investigate diverse scientific research topics, such as tracking environmental changes, discovering new species, and assessing the impact of invasive species. By making these collections available online, researchers, conservationists, and the public can better understand how marine ecosystems are changing over time.

Over the course of the grant, the Museum of Natural History at the University of Colorado Boulder (UCM) successfully captured high-quality images of over 1,000 specimens, surpassing the original goal. Additionally, the team mapped the locations of over 3,200 specimen records, allowing scientists to study how species have moved or declined over the years. The data will soon be available on platforms such as InvertEBase and iDigBio, where anyone can explore them. This project ensures that valuable scientific information, previously locked away in paper records, will soon be just a click away for researchers, educators, and nature enthusiasts.

One of the project’s major focuses was on two key groups of marine invertebrates: mud shrimps (Upogebia) and invasive isopods (Orthione). Orthione is a parasitic species that has invaded American coastal waters, preventing native mud shrimps from reproducing. Understanding how these species have spread over time is crucial for protecting native marine life. By digitizing historical collections, scientists can track when and where Orthione first appeared, how it has spread, and what that means for the future of marine ecosystems.

In addition to supporting research, the project placed a strong emphasis on education and public engagement. The museum developed hands-on activities about marine life for its Girls At the Museum Exploring Science (GAMES) program, encouraging young students to explore careers in science. The museum also created “Wonder of the Week” social media posts to highlight fascinating invertebrate specimens and led K-12 school tours that introduced children to the hidden world of marine invertebrates. These activities helped connect people of all ages with the importance of ocean biodiversity and conservation.

This digitization effort also benefits a wide range of scientific research. The newly available data will support studies on how parasites spread, how small ocean creatures interact with bacteria, and how species adapt to environmental changes. By comparing past and present distributions of marine invertebrates, scientists can detect early warning signs of species decline and inform conservation efforts.

This project also provided valuable hands-on experience for undergraduate and graduate students. Volunteers and student employees learned how to digitize specimens, map collection data, and manage museum databases—skills that will help them pursue careers in science, conservation, and museum work.

By bringing these historic collections into the digital age, UCM is making marine biodiversity data more accessible than ever. Once fully integrated into online databases, these collections will serve as a powerful resource for researchers studying environmental changes, species distributions, and conservation challenges in marine ecosystems. The project has not only expanded access to critical biodiversity data but has also helped build a foundation for future scientific discoveries and public education. Whether for students learning about ocean life, or nature lovers exploring biodiversity from their homes, this project ensures that valuable museum collections can be used to inform and inspire for generations to come.
